body:
Could we introduce a commandline flag for the regular syncthing binary like e.g `-force-gui-auth` ?

If the flag is present and authentication has not been setup previously, syncthing should create new credentials and persist them in the config.

As the config only contains the hash, we would need to provide the cleartext password somehow. The question is if we can simply log the created credentials.

Good idea about the flag to prevent the security hole.  But I think the user experience is really bad if the user doesn't supply the password, but has to find an automatically generated one, then log in and change it.  At least on SynoCommunity, there are many packages asking for credentials during setup to protect some software's admin GUI.  I'd like to stick to that pattern, so the only missing component in that case is the bcrypt hashing and (offline) `config.xml` manipulation.  I wouldn't know how to display the generated credentials to the user after the service has been started for the first time -- that happens after setup.

A web based setup triggered via commandline flag would be the best solution for the user. e.g https://10.0.0.2:8384/setup

This is also what Nextcloud offers with their web installer.

What environment / workflow do you have in mind for this?

I can speak for Synology's DSM that it would be much more difficult than what I am working on, where this issue would be the last missing puzzle piece.
There is a `syncthing [serve] --generate` which probably should be `syncthing generate` and which could take `--gui-auth-user user --gui-auth-password password` type things.

> There is a `syncthing [serve] --generate` which probably should be `syncthing generate` and which could take `--gui-auth-user user --gui-auth-password password` type things.

Right, that sounds like a useful extension.  What does it do if the config is already there?  Will it overwrite existing certificates?  I don't intend to use it on upgrades, only installation.  But better safe than sorry when it comes to losing keys.

```
jb@kvin:~ % syncthing --generate tmp/foo
14:03:50 INFO: Device ID: CB3XYZC-LU3GLEE-RCB36VE-ROAC7LJ-PM25V6Q-ORNWXTD-DWM7LEU-WQCZKAQ
14:03:50 INFO: Default folder created and/or linked to new config
jb@kvin:~ % syncthing --generate tmp/foo
14:03:51 WARNING: Key exists; will not overwrite.
14:03:51 INFO: Device ID: CB3XYZC-LU3GLEE-RCB36VE-ROAC7LJ-PM25V6Q-ORNWXTD-DWM7LEU-WQCZKAQ
14:03:51 WARNING: Config exists; will not overwrite.
jb@kvin:~ %
```

Though if it gains parameters it might make sense to make the config step a read-modify-write to apply those parameters. That would also make it a password reset / recover utility.

Great idea, I think I would manage to implement such an addition.  Thanks for the pointer.

Should we also do the rename from a flag to a subcommand then?
Yeah, I'd break it out into a sub command. Bonus points, if it's easy, to retain the current switch as an alias for compatibility, but not if it's not easy.

I'm a bit confused about the different subcommand implementations.  There's `alecthomas/kong` being used mainly, but also `urfave/cli` for the `cli` subcommand (probably because kong does not play well with auto-generated options).  I assume integration with kong is easier, but if you prefer urfave/cli for future additions, I will comply.  And I suppose a separate package is not needed, like for decrypt?

`kong` is the thing. `cli` uses something else for historical reasons as it (vastly) predates subcommands in Syncthing and also `kong` itself. I'd put it in a separate package like `decrypt` so that all non-`serve` subcommands live in separate packages under `cmd/syncthing`.

Thanks, will do.  This is the draft structure then:

```
acolomb@barnov:~/src/syncthing/bin$ ./syncthing --help generate
Usage: syncthing generate

Generate key and config, then exit

Flags:
  -h, --help                   Show context-sensitive help.

      --no-console             Hide console window
      --config=PATH            Set configuration directory (config and keys)
      --home=PATH              Set configuration and data directory
      --no-default-folder      Don't create the "default" folder on first startup ($STNODEFAULTFOLDER)
      --gui-user=STRING        Override GUI authentication user name
      --gui-password=STRING    Override GUI authentication password (use - to read from standard input)
```

This reuses the common `--home` and `--config` parameters for consistency, and uses the default location if none is supplied.  We could converge on only `--config` here as compatibility doesn't matter, but user habit may be enough reason?

Sorry, one more technical question about Go packages: If I want to use a common options structure from the cmd/syncthing main package within cmd/syncthing/generate, how to do that without an import cycle?  Same goes for the convenience function `ensureDir()`.  Copy it?  Factor out to own package?  Right now it seems a separate package brings much more headaches than just another struct in `main.go`...

Logging is another pain point: `decrypt` uses `log` directly, while `serve` has its fancy logger which is used e. g. in `ensureDir()` so that's not easily moved to a utility package.

If you need something to be common, putting it in the (new) `generate` package should avoid the cycle. I wouldn't go with `--home` and `--config` for generate, since it takes the relevant path as a parameter already.

(Not sure about the logging. Fanciness not required in `generate`, I'd say.)
There's already a `cmd/syncthing/cmdutil` package. I didn't look at it again, but I assume it's there exactly for this kind of purpose.

> I wouldn't go with `--home` and `--config` for generate, since it takes the relevant path as a parameter already.

The old option does, but the new subcommand should be consistent with the others IMO. Including the ability to not supply a path at all so it uses the default. Which I think the old option should have supported from the start.

I'll see what I can come up with, trying to keep it simple. Checking for these two args is only about 3 lines of code ;-)

> (Not sure about the logging. Fanciness not required in `generate`, I'd say.)

What I'd like to avoid is having several implementations of the `generate()` function which can get out of sync. When it's done as part of regular startup for "serve", using the advanced logger makes sense and I don't want to affect that mode of operation. But for the subcommand logging can be very simple. Let's discuss this further when I have a PR with hands on code.
I'd be wary of passing passwords on the commandline, given things like bash history etc. Reading it from stdin would be better.

> I'd be wary of passing passwords on the commandline, given things like bash history etc. Reading it from stdin would be better.

That is a first-class consideration I have already implemented in my prototype.  Will make a PR when it's cleaned up.

I'm a little bit stuck in my implementation when trying to actually modify the config.  If there is no file yet, `syncthing.DefaultConfig()` gives us a `config.Wrapper`.  I would do the same when it does exist by calling `config.Load()`.  But that wrapper doesn't really work for modifications unless I start its `Serve()` method with a new context etc.  That seems overly complicated all in all, just to open an XML file, modify two tags, and write it back.  Note this subcommand is just a simple, single-threaded script context where there are no services running and thus no Committers to take care of.

Do you think using the `ReadXML()` / `WriteXML()` functions directly for the generate subcommand would suffice?  Or is there a simpler way to actually make use of the `config.Wrapper`?

issue.title: lib/config: Move the bcrypt password hashing to GUIConfiguration

issue.body:
### Purpose

This is part of the solution for #8021, but makes sense as an isolated change.

What hash is used to store the password should ideally be an implementation detail, so that every user of the GUIConfiguration object automatically agrees on how to handle it.  That is currently distribututed over the confighandler.go and api_auth.go files, plus tests.

Add the `SetHasedPassword()` / `CompareHashedPassword()` API to keep the hashing method encapsulated.  Add a separate test for it and adjust other users and tests.  Remove all deprecated imports of the bcrypt package.

### Testing

`TestGUIPasswordHash()` added for the new config API.  Adjusted `lib/api/api_auth_test.go` to the different `authBasic()` function signature.  All tests still passing.

body: Getting a wrapper, stating it's serve method and doing modification seem the cleanest solution to me.
I'm waiting on #8028 to get merged so I can rebase my branch for this and make a PR.  Any chance that can happen before .rc1?
